citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Female Cavalier King Charles dog (tag #93)'s left eye was noted to be less moist as her right eye, had some mild
discharge on the surface and mild reddening of the white part of the eyeball. This condition was not under treatment at
time of inspection but was noted in her April physical exam and the facility representative indicated was under prescribed
treatment then until medication ran out and it had gotten better. Observations of her eye today suggest the condition is not
resolved and needs to be re-evaluated by the attending veterinarian (AV) to ensure treatment can be given to prevent
discomfort and worsening of the condition. Ensure that the AV is contacted to re-evaluate this dog's condition and follow
the prescribed treatment plan.
***Correct by 11/23/2024.

At least 9 adult dogs were observed to not have their official ID on a collar. Each dog is assigned and has a an official ID
number, however some dogs have chewed each other's collars and are in need of a new collar to attach their ID tag to.
Lack of an ID tag on a dog can make it difficult to track husbandry and health of of the dogs. Ensure to obtain replacement
collars so that dogs can wear their official identification.
***Correct by December 20, 2024.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
On the outdoor run portions of primary enclosures, waste has not been removed daily. Removal of excreta daily from
primary enclosures helps maintain dogs' living areas more comfortable and helps protect their health. Ensure to maintain
a daily routine of removing waste and excreta from primary enclosures daily.
***Correct from 11/22/2024 forward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Female Cavalier King Charles dog (tag #93)'s left eye was noted to be less moist as her right eye, had some mild 
discharge on the surface and mild reddening of the white part of the eyeball. This condition was not under treatment at 
time of inspection but was noted in her April physical exam and the facility representative indicated was under prescribed 
treatment then until medication ran out and it had gotten better. Observations of her eye today suggest the condition is not 
resolved and needs to be re-evaluated by the attending veterinarian (AV) to ensure treatment can be given to prevent 
discomfort and worsening of the condition. Ensure that the AV is contacted to re-evaluate this dog's condition and follow 
the prescribed treatment plan.  
***Correct by 11/23/2024. 
2.50(a)(1) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
At least 9 adult dogs were observed to not have their official ID on a collar. Each dog is assigned and has a an official ID 
number, however some dogs have chewed each other's collars and are in need of a new collar to attach their ID tag to. 
Lack of an ID tag on a dog can make it difficult to track husbandry and health of of the dogs. Ensure to obtain replacement 
collars so that dogs can wear their official identification.  
***Correct by December 20, 2024. 
3.11(a) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
On the outdoor run portions of primary enclosures, waste has not been removed daily. Removal of excreta daily from 
primary enclosures helps maintain dogs' living areas more comfortable and helps protect their health. Ensure to maintain 
a daily routine of removing waste and excreta from primary enclosures daily.  
***Correct from 11/22/2024 forward. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.

n
